results.title: Boys on film 3: Beyond gravity. Bad news bachelors. Resonance
results.creator_credit: James Wallace Productions, Realworld Pictures and Resonance Films
results.brief_description: Three short films from Australia and New Zealand featuring gay male characters. “Bad news bachelors” Set in Sydney, this short film follows thirty-something Stuart as he roams the city’s cafes, bars and cruising areas looking for a man to love but finding only sex with a series of likeable men - none of whom offer the likelihood of a relationship. “Resonance” This short experimental dance film opens with a vicious gay bashing, then pieces together the relationship between the victim, the basher and his girlfriend. Homophobia and misogyny are linked in the character of the basher. The plot is deliberately ambiguous. The basher resembles the martial arts instructor who is the rescuer of the victim. Gesture and dance are used as a form of interior monologue exploring the way this act of violence resonates through the lives of the characters. “Beyond Gravity”: Richard spends his time fantasising about outerspace and the cosmos, an activity which antagonises friends and family. Then one day he meets Johnny, a handsome Italian man, with an enormous appetite for life, who offers him love and an escape from the monotony of work. This short New Zealand film is a joyous celebration of the love between two eccentrics. It is also a refreshingly matter-of-fact and comic treatment of a romance between two men who both have their sights aimed firmly amongst the stars.

results.title: Boy with a knife
results.brief_description: A powerful re-enactment of a case story from the files of a Los Angeles Youth Service Agency. Shows how a group worker attempts to reach a gang of boys who are headed for delinquency; he plans a preventative action and shows how he attempts to carry out the plans.

results.title: Boy in the garden
results.brief_description: The enchantment to be found in a bush-like garden by a young boy who reflects the spirit shown in the statue of Pan playing his pipes. Scampering, dabbling his toes, floating flower petals and pressing his face close to the flowers, he shows us his fascination in the wonder of nature. A film without commentary and with flute accompaniment. Music: Nancy Tow.

results.title: Boxing for boys: attack, defence and ringcraft
results.creator_credit: Colin Bell, Frank Wells and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the chief form of attack and defence; section of the glove to be used in hitting, portion of the body to be hit; correct stance; the straight left; the right hook; the swing; a lead and an uppercut; side stepping; the cross counter; the parry, blocking; slipping and ducking.

results.title: Box kite to swing wing
results.brief_description: A history of the Royal Australian Air Force from the original Australian Flying Corps to todays modern aircraft of Macchi jet trainers, medium range Hercules and Iriquois helicopters. Shows their operations in World Wars I and II, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam plus their peacetime operations.

results.title: Bowling action
results.creator_credit: Denys Parsons, Brian Smith, Dorothy Grayson, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Realist Films
results.brief_description: An analysis of the slow-medium bowling action of Ray Smith of Essex. The movements of Smith’s body in a run-up and delivery are shown and analysed, using normal speed, slow motion, and suspended shots. At four key positions of the action, H.P. Crabtree illustrates a method by which boys can obtain concentrated practice in pitching the ball for both length and direction. Commentary by John Arlott and filmed on location at Lord’s (MCC), the home of cricket.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Denys Parsons, Brian Smith, Dorothy Grayson, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Realist Films

results.title: Bow bells
results.creator_credit: Anthony Simmons, Leon Clore and Harlequin Productions
results.brief_description: In “The London Spy”, Ned Ward’s delightful account of low life in the 18th Century, we are told how “the joyful alarm of Bow Bells call’d the weary apprentices from their work to unhitch their folded shutters and batten up their shops till next morning”. This is the atmosphere evoked by this film presenting faces, streets, buildings around the dock-yards of London’s East End. There is no commentary: the photographed scenes are accompanied by satirically matched snatches of music hall songs.

results.title: Bovine contagious pleuropneumonia
results.brief_description: This film traces the introduction and spread of the disease throughout Australia; why it persists in the north and how in spite of all precautions it occasionally infiltrates to the south. The main section of the film depicts in detail the characteristic symptoms and post-mortem findings, the effectiveness of vaccination, and the nature of present and past research work of the Division of Animal Health and Production.
